Award.AwardTitle: Resolving competing orders and symmetry-breaking in cuprate and iron pnictide high temperature superconductors using infrared Hall measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract

Superconductors conduct electricity without any resistance and have provided fascinating new science as well as important new technologies (from medical imaging to high energy particle accelerators to telecommunications filters to maglev trains). One of the biggest technological challenges of conventional superconductors is that they have to be cooled to very low temperatures using expensive and increasingly scarce liquid helium. This award supports research on new materials that superconduct at significantly higher temperatures and have challenged our understanding of superconductivity. These high temperature superconductors have attracted a great deal of attention in the last three decades for their rich and often unresolved behavior as well as their technological applications. The researchers at the State University of New York at Buffalo use new infrared techniques they developed to explore how these materials behave as a function of chemical composition, magnetic field, temperature, and probing frequency. The project involves graduate and undergraduate students. The outreach program involves a public high school in Buffalo and will have a large impact on urban mixed-income public school students.


Technical Abstract

This award from the Condensed Matter Physics program in the Division of Materials Research supports research on cuprate and iron pnictide high temperature superconductors (HTS) at the State University of New York at Buffalo. HTS materials have attracted a great deal of attention in the last three decades for their rich and often unresolved behavior as well as their technological applications. Due to the characteristic energy scale of many of these properties and the unique ability of magneto-polarimetry to probe asymmetries and order in the electronic structure, these HTS are extremely well-suited for exploration using terahertz Hz (2-6 meV) and infrared (IR: 100-1200 meV) Hall measurements. The principal investigator studies a wide range of HTS materials as a function of doping, temperature, probe energy, and magnetic field. The sensitivity and broad spectral extent of the proposed measurements provide new insights into the unusual pseudogap phase (PGP) in these HTS materials, as well as new information about charge, spin, and magnetic ordering. A key question in the cuprates is whether the PGP is simply a precursor to superconductivity or whether it is a fully fledged new phase with its own broken symmetry. The objective is to provide insight into the mechanism(s) breaking the symmetry. In the iron pnictides, the work explores a wide range of anomalous behavior, including anomalous optical absorption far above the superconducting gap, unusual spectral weight transfer in the IR, possible coexistence of magnetism and superconductivity, spin-ordering, and a PGP. The research involves undergraduate students and two PhD students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: We studied a variety of two dimensional systems ranging from cuprate and iron-based high temperature superconductors (HTS) to graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD). In cuprate HTS, we have observed strong infrared linear dichroism signals in a broad range of doping, temperature, and energy, from THz to visible (3-2330 meV). This is strong evidence for rotational symmetry breaking due to nematicity and is the first probe to explore the energy dependence of this symmetry breaking over a wide energy range. In many samples, the symmetry-breaking signal peaks near 400 meV, which could be related the mid-infrared peak that is associated with the pseudogap phase. In iron pnictide HTS we discovered a large hysteretic/ferromagnetic infrared Faraday signal in spite of the fact that other measurements suggest that the films contain almost no iron impurities. Although the signal is hysteretic and is clearly associated with ferromagnetism, the temperature dependence of the signal may be connected with superconductivity since it shows features near the superconducting transition temperature. In graphene we have discovered three new phenomena: 1) a gated graphene monolayer can produce large changes (~ 6?) in the polarization of infrared transmitted light with the application of a small voltage (~10 V); 2) due to steps in the SiC substrate, graphene on SiC shows strong anisotropic conductivity which makes it behave like a dichroic linear polarizer, producing large rotation and ellipticity in the reflected and transmitted infrared radiation; 3) due to the optical properties of SiC, the infrared Kerr signal at a photon energy of 120 meV is enhanced by a factor of up to 68 in a variety of films on SiC. Finally, we explored TMD both at UB and at the Technical University of Munich. 

Broader Impact: Three PhD students at UB were supported by this grant. One graduated in May 2018 and is now a process engineer at Intel. The second finished his PhD in January 2019 and the third will graduate in spring 2020. Two undergraduate students at UB were coauthors on one of our papers that was recently accepted for publication in PRB. We expect that our discovery of voltage-controlled polarization modulation in gated graphene could have technological applications, for example IR communications, and are writing a new patent disclosure. The PI met with Buffalo public school (BPS) teachers and administrators, including the BPS district superintendent Dr. Kriner Cash, to make plans using radio-controlled (RC) flight to teach/motivate STEM in BPS. The PI worked with three schools on creating RC flying clubs. He ran a three-hour workshop with approximately 20 BPS teachers on teaching science and technology using RC aviation and presented ?Radio-controlled flight in the classroom?? at the Western New York Physics Teachers Alliance. The PI also presented a public lecture entitled "A physicist?s view of frequency," at "Frequencies: Science and Art Cabaret 23," on February 26, 2019.
